zone.line: Our of her eyes, for which it said it thirsted
As one bit by a dipsas; & with her
It made its childish confidence, & told her
All it had known or seen, for it saw much
Yet idly reasoned what it saw—& called her—
For whence it sprung it knew not nor do I—
Mother dear Mother
The Spirit running to Asia
Mother dearest Mother!
May I then talk with thee as I was wont? 335
May I then hide mine eyes in thy soft arms
After thy looks have made them tired of joy?
May I then play beside thee the long noons
When work is none in the bright silent air?
Asia
I love thee gentlest being, and henceforth 340
Can cherish thee unenvied— speak I pray
Thy p simple talk once solaced ... now delights.
Spirit
Mother, I am grown wiser though a child
Cannot be wise like thee, within this day
And happier too, happier & wiser both.
